candidateA.name: Mark Carney
candidateA.summary: Mark Carney's economic promises focus on strengthening Canada's trade relationships and reducing reliance on the U.S. He pledges to protect Canadian workers and industries through retaliatory tariffs and strategic investments, while also aiming to foster internal trade and eliminate federal barriers. Carney also proposes middle-class tax cuts and targeted support for sectors like the auto industry and infrastructure.

candidateB.name: Pierre Poilievre
candidateB.summary: Pierre Poilievre's economic promises center on tax cuts, including a 15% income tax reduction for average workers and eliminating certain business tax write-offs. He pledges to stimulate resource development by repealing anti-development laws, expediting project approvals, and building infrastructure like pipelines. Additionally, he aims to promote interprovincial trade and support workers affected by tariffs through income replacement and flexible employment insurance.

differences.carney_stance: Proposes tax cuts, specifically a middle-class tax cut.
differences.poilievre_stance: Proposes broad tax cuts, including a 15% income tax cut for the average worker and cuts on investment.

differences.carney_stance: Commitment to eliminate barriers to trade and labor mobility within Canada.
Commitment to use every dollar generated by tariffs to protect workers.
differences.poilievre_stance: Provide support to workers who lose their jobs due to tariffs

differences.carney_stance: Commitment to respond with tariffs if the U.S. imposes tariffs.
differences.poilievre_stance: Impose counter-tariffs on products that can be manufactured in Canada

differences.carney_stance: Protect supply management, commitment to never discuss supply management in trade negotiations.
Eliminate duplicative federal regulations and establish a one-window approval process for major projects.
differences.poilievre_stance: Repeal Bill C69 and replace it with a law for faster permits.

differences.point: Reducing reliance on the United States and building new trading relations
differences.carney_stance: Commitment to reduce reliance on the United States and build new trading relations
differences.poilievre_stance: Build a new national pipeline to bypass the American market and sell oil to Europe.

similarities.point: Commitment to removing barriers to trade within Canada.
similarities.carney_stance: Commitment to expand efforts to end barriers hindering trade and labor mobility and eliminate federal barriers to interprovincial trade.
similarities.poilievre_stance: Promote free trade between provinces and break down trade barriers between provinces.

similarities.point: Commitment to using tariff revenues to support workers.
similarities.carney_stance: Commitment to use every dollar from retaliatory tariffs to protect Canadian workers.
similarities.poilievre_stance: Provide support to workers who lose their jobs due to tariffs.

similarities.carney_stance: Commitment to retaliate against U.S. tariffs with Canadian trade actions.
similarities.poilievre_stance: Impose counter-tariffs on products that can be manufactured in Canada

similarities.carney_stance: Establish a one-window approval process for major projects and eliminate duplicative federal regulations.
similarities.poilievre_stance: Repeal C69 and replace it with a law for faster permits and Grant permits for mining within 6 months
